post.title: Enforce environmental laws before there’s a chemical fire

children.text: Texas has not made before-the-fact enforcement a strong goal, often doing the bare minimum allowed under federal law.

After the State of Texas filed lawsuits against KMCO and Intercontinental Terminals Company after the chemical fires in 2019, University of Houston Professor Victor B. Flatt writes in an op-ed for the Houston Chronicle: "Unfortunately, while after-the-fact penalties are important in any good enforcement system, they are not sufficient by themselves to alter behavior to prevent such harms in the first place. And that should be the ultimate goal of state enforcement.

"To avoid (or at least lessen) similar harm in the future, the state needs to practice effective enforcement, and that requires money and time spent before a disaster occurs. ... Unfortunately, Texas has not made before-the-fact enforcement a strong goal, often doing the bare minimum allowed under federal law. That’s even though parts of the state, including the Houston area, are heavily industrialized and face a large number of risks."
